sources.data_found: Premise cluster GPU specifications: Nine compute nodes each contain two NVIDIA k80 GPU cards (9 × 2 = 18 K80 GPUs). One compute node contains a single NVIDIA v100 GPU card. Fourteen compute nodes each contain a single NVIDIA a100 GPU card. Performance calculations mention 1 h100 GPU node with 30 TFlops. Total 26 nodes have GPUs out of 70 total compute nodes.
87 Total Graduate Students in Computer Science department. 66% International Breakout. 176 Applied, 113 Accepted, 27 Enrolled.

In 2023, 3,916 degrees were awarded across all undergraduate and graduate programs at University of New Hampshire-Main Campus. Most popular Bachelors concentrations included General Business Administration (618 degrees), General Psychology (211 degrees).

student_data.notes: Graduate CS count based on Peterson's data showing 87 total graduate students in CS department. PhD count estimated from typical PhD cohort size (approximately 20% of graduate students). Undergraduate CS count estimated based on typical CS department sizes at similarly-sized state universities with ~11,365 undergrads, assuming approximately 3.5% CS majors.

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: 9 nodes × 2 K80 GPUs per node = 18 K80 GPUs total. K80 is dual-GPU card with 24GB total VRAM.

gpu_resources.notes:
PREMISE CLUSTER GPU CALCULATIONS:
- K80 GPUs: 9 nodes × 2 GPUs/node = 18 K80 GPUs
- V100 GPUs: 1 node × 1 GPU = 1 V100
- A100 GPUs: 14 nodes × 1 GPU = 14 A100 (assumed 80GB variant as specific memory not stated)
- H100 GPUs: 1 node × 1 GPU = 1 H100 (mentioned in performance calculations)

Total GPU nodes: 26 out of 70 total compute nodes in Premise cluster.

analysis_notes: UNH operates the Premise HPC cluster with 70 compute nodes total, 26 of which have GPUs. The cluster uses a condo compute model where researchers can buy nodes. GPU resources include older generation K80s as well as newer A100 and a single H100. Student enrollment data shows moderate CS program size appropriate for a state university of UNH's size.
